TEXT: The applicant , Mr R , is a GPE national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is represented before the ORG by PERSON , GPE , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE , the applicant ’s daughter PERSON reported to the police that the applicant had interfered with her children X. and Y. At the same time , the applicant ’s stepson PERSON reported that the applicant had abused him during his childhood .

On DATE , the applicant was arrested . He was charged DATE with CARDINAL offences of indecent assault against his grandson X. and his stepson PERSON On or about CARDINAL DATE , the prosecution submitted a revised indictment containing CARDINAL counts ( CARDINAL concerning J. , DATE concerning X. and CARDINAL concerning Y. ) .
On DATE , the judge ordered that the indictment be severed in relation to counts CARDINAL ( “ the second trial ” ) and counts CARDINAL ( “ the first trial ” ) .

On DATE , the first trial commenced . On DATE , the jury returned a unanimous not guilty verdict in relation to counts CARDINAL and CARDINAL but were unable even to reach a majority verdict on counts CARDINAL concerning the applicant ’s grandson X.

On DATE , the prosecution formally offered no evidence on counts CARDINAL - CARDINAL and the judge directed the jury to acquit the applicant . The applicant made an application for reimbursement of his costs pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Prosecution of Offences Act DATE . The judge ruled that the matter of costs should be dealt with at the conclusion of the second trial .
On DATE , the second trial began before the same judge . The jury returned unanimous not guilty verdicts on CARDINAL counts .

On DATE , the defence made an application for reimbursement of costs for both trials ( altogether some GBP CARDINAL ) . In his decision DATE , the judge rejected the application for costs , stating as follows :

“ I have a discretion , and CARDINAL of the matters that I have to bear in mind is this : has this defendant contributed to the prosecution that was instigated against him ? I say this : so far as the grandson is concerned , the defendant took it upon himself to instruct the grandson in certain sexual matters , which in my view were no concern of his at all but were entirely a matter for the mother .

So far as the son is concerned we have heard in the course of the trial certain sexual matters that the defendant himself said took place between he and his son DATE using language as neutrally as possible , episodes that the defendant described I consider to be bizarre DATE and I have in mind the sexual contact that the defendant took place between himself and his son .

Looking at this matter , therefore in the round , I am in no doubt that the defendant himself has contributed by his own behaviour and his own conduct to the prosecution that was instigated against him .
Accordingly the applications for costs are refused . ”

Counsel for the applicant sought to correct the judge concerning the “ sexual training ” that the applicant had allegedly provided to his grandson ( DATE at the time ) , asserting that the evidence was that the applicant had sought to discourage his grandson from playing with his genitals . The judge responded :

“ But nevertheless , it is my view that the defendant ’s behaviour was entirely inappropriate , if there was an , shall we say correction or help needed , it was no matter for him DATE it was a matter for the child ’s mother . ”

On DATE , an application was made to ORG for reconsideration of the award of costs . A different judge held that he had no power to interfere with the decision and there was no power for ORG to review the matter either .
Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE provides insofar as relevant :
“ Where-
( b ) any person is tried on indictment and acquitted on any count in the indictment ;
ORG may make a defendant ’s costs order in favour of the accused . ”
On DATE , Lord PERSON gave a Practice Direction of ORG ) concerning costs in criminal proceedings :
“ In ORG .

CARDINAL . Where a person ... has been acquitted on any count in the indictment , the court may make a defendant ’s costs order in his favour . Such an order should usually be made ... unless there are positive reasons for not doing so . Examples of such reasons are : ( a ) the defendant ’s own conduct has brought suspicion on himself and has misled the prosecution into thinking that the case is stronger than it is .... ” ( Practice Direction ( Crime : Costs ) [ DATE ] CARDINAL WLR CARDINAL ) .
The right of appeal to ORG ) is against conviction or sentence pursuant to section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE . As the applicant was acquitted , he had no such right of appeal .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE provides that ORG has the same powers of judicial review over ORG as over an inferior court save in respect of ORG ’s
“ jurisdiction in matters relating to trial on indictment ” .
In the case of Re Sampson [ DATE ] CARDINAL WLR CARDINAL , a case concerning a legal aid contribution order at the end of a trial on indictment , Lord Bridge of GPE said :

“ ... certain orders made at the conclusion of a trial on indictment are excluded from judicial review as ‘ relating to trial on indictment’ not because they affect the conduct of the trial , but rather because they are themselves an integral part of the trial process . ”

In that case , the judge ’s order could not , therefore , be judicially reviewed . In the case of ORG and Others ( [ DATE ] CARDINAL WLR CARDINAL ) , ORG rejected a suggestion that the above proposition in Re PERSON was wrong .
